There are countless problems with Pascal's Wager.
 
 The one I always strive to point out is that one cannot change a belief based merely on a desire to change belief. I am incapable of believing that 2+2=5 if I already believe that 2+2=4 unless I have reason to believe that this is true. "Reason to believe" does not include arguments from consequence: Nobody will believe that they have the ability to fly merely because the consequence of the ability to fly has the potential for great fun.
 Unfortunately, it is true that people really do delude themselves into believing what they want to believe instead of what they should believe based on evidence.
 
 A very closely related flaw is that PW makes truth immaterial to determining belief.
 
 PW does not apply proper probabilities to the possibilities.
 
 PW does not explore the aspect of which god. Even Homer Simpson found this flaw. It works for Ahuramazda of Zoroastrianism just as well as it works for YHWH/Jehovah.
 
 The assumption that nothing is lost when a nonexistent God is believed to exist is false. It saddens me that smart, kind people sometimes spend so much time, effort, and money on what amounts to superstition and has little effect, when those resources could be put toward something that has a much greater impact.
 
 If God really exists and knows who truly believes in Him, He will know who believes in him based on their genuine beliefs and who "believes" in him based on some ridiculously erroneous application of game theory.

 
 I believe this is the true flaw in Pascal's argument. One cannot will oneself to believe something because the consequences of doing so seem like a better deal. 
 
 Like electrolyte, Sam Harris is more articultate on this topic than me:
 
Reason is a compulsion, not a choice. Just as one cannot intentionally startle oneself, one cannot knowingly believe a proposition on bad evidence. If you doubt this, imagine hearing the following account of a failed New Year's resolution: 
 
 "This year, I vowed to be more rational, but by the end of January, I found that I had fallen back into my old ways, believing things for bad reasons. Currently, I believe that smoking is harmless, that my dead brother will return to life in the near future, and that I am destined to marry Angelina Jolie, just because these beliefs make me feel good and give my life meaning."
 
 This is not how our minds work. To believe a proposition, we must also believe that we believe it because it is true. While lapses in rationality can often be detected in retrospect, they always occur in the dark, outside of consciousness. In every present moment, a belief entails the concurrent conviction that we are not just fooling ourselves.
